awd_titl_txt: Algorithm Development and Analysis for Non-Newtonian Fluids Interacting with Elastic and Poroelastic Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
This research concerns the development and rigorous analysis of stable and efficient numerical schemes for non-Newtonian fluid - structure interactions (FSI). The study will be focused on partitioning schemes of an implicit type for the coupled model systems that allow each subproblem to be solved independently using existing local solvers in a fixed/moving domain setting. Stability and accuracy properties of numerical methods will be investigated using non-Newtonian fluid and poroelastic/elastic structure models. The theoretical investigation will provide a solid foundation and guidance to the further development of numerical algorithms.  Because of the many important biological and engineering processes involving non-Newtonian fluid flows, there is a great demand for mathematical support in these applications. This research will provide an underlying mathematical foundation for non-Newtonian flows in a multiphysical setting.
 
 
The technical goal of this project is to develop algorithms and analyze numerical schemes for two coupled systems: (a) quasi-Newtoinan fluid - poroelastic structure and (b) viscoelastic fluid - elastic structure. For system (a) the PI will focus on the development and analysis of a nonlinear operator, where a solution to the operator equation yields subsystem solutions satisfying interface conditions of the whole coupled system. Advantages of this approach over the previously developed optimization approach are the flexibility to choose a nonlinear solver and that no extra coding effort is needed as the adjoint system is no longer involved in a solution process. Since it is expected that the linearized operator is not self-adjoint, the linear operator equation should be solved by an iterative solver for a non-self-adjoint problem. When a partitioned scheme is considered for simulating viscoelastic FSI, extra difficulty is encountered due to the lack of information on the stress along the moving boundary and movement of inlet and outlet boundaries along the interface of two subsystems. The PI will investigate various choices for a stress boundary value and their effect on a solution of FSI.  Another issue with the viscoelastic FSI is the size of the fluid problem to be solved in each time step (or in each internal iteration), which may require an operator splitting based on a temporal discretization scheme such as a fractional time step method. To tackle this, the PI will investigate various time stepping schemes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The primary contribution of the research is the development of robust numerical schemes for non-Newtonian flows in a multi-physics setting and mathematical studies of these problems modeled by complex equations coupled through interface conditions. 

This project focused on developing and analyzing numerical methods for fluid-structure interaction problems involving non-Newtonian fluid flows and elastic (or porous or poroelastic) structures. Several different problems were considered for the project: (i) decoupling algorithms by optimization for the generalized Stokes-Biot system,  (ii) space-time domain decomposition for non-Newtonian fluid flows interacting with an elastic (or porous or poroelastic) structure, and (iii) least squares approximations for local problems (viscoelastic fluid and poroelastic structure). For (i) and (ii), we studied implicit type partitioning schemes for coupled model systems that allow us to solve each subproblem independently using existing local solvers. In (i) and also in most existing methods for fluid-structure interaction problems, the model equations are first discretized uniformly in time using an implicit discretization scheme. And then, at each time step, the steady-state subproblem is solved iteratively, exchanging interface data. Drawbacks of these methods include using the same time step in subdomains and exchanging information at each time step. Using a uniform time step throughout the entire time domain is inefficient for applications where the time scales in subdomains could be largely different. To improve the efficiency of the numerical scheme, in (ii), we developed and analyzed parallel decoupling methods for which both space and time domains are discretized locally.  This approach is the so-called space-time domain decomposition method in which the dynamic system is decoupled into dynamic subsystems defined on the subdomains. Therefore, non-matching time step sizes and non-matching space grids can be employed for subdomain problems. Also, in (iii), we studied least squares finite element methods to discretize local problems. Least squares finite element methods improve the efficiency of local solvers for model equations with many variables such as viscoelastic fluid or poroelastic model because they provide the flexibility for the choice of finite element spaces, and no stabilization is needed. The project results have been summarized in 6 journal papers and 2 M.S. theses, and more results will be reported in one Ph.D. thesis and one or two more journal papers in the future.

Broader impacts of the project include training motivated students prepared to enter STEM disciplines, particularly in mathematically modeling fluid flows in a multi-physics setting. This project partially supported one Ph.D. student and two M.S. students. Also, one undergraduate student was involved in the project, worked with the Ph.D. student, and co-authored one journal paper. The Ph.D. graduate student has co-authored two journal papers so far and is expected to publish more by graduation. The PI presented the results of this research at regional, national, and international conferences and gave lectures at seminars or colloquia. The multi-physics problems we studied are of interest to related scientific and engineering communities. Studying these strongly coupled nonlinear problems leads to a better understanding and a unifying description of complex real-life processes.

 


Last Modified: 07/14/2022
Modified by: Hyesuk K Lee
